name: acrylonitrile production, Sohio process | acrylonitrile | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8976/documentation

This dataset represents the multioutput-process "Sohio propylene ammoxidation." The process delivers the co-products acrylonitrile, hydrogen cyanide, and acetonitrile from 1 kg of propylene.  The raw materials and energy consumptions are modelled with literature data.  The emissions are estimated.  Infrastructure is included with a default value.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From the reception of propylene at the factory gate.

This activity ends with the production of acrylonitrile, hydrogen cyanide and acetonitrile based off of the ammoxidation of 1 kg of propylene.  This dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: In the Sohio process propene, oxygen (as air), and ammonia are catalytically converted directly to acrylonitrile using a fluidized-bed reactor operated at temperatures of 400 – 500 °C and gauge pressures of 30 – 200 kPa (0.3 – 2 bar):;Approximately stoichometric amounts of the starting materials are passed through the reactor with residence times of a few seconds. The process is highly selective, requiring no recycling to produce high acrylonitrile yields of approximately 0.8 – 0.9 kg from 1 kg of propene. Acetonitrile (0.02 – 0.11 kg) and hydrogen cyanide (HCN, 0.15 – 0.20 kg) are the principal byproducts (from 1 kg propene). The heat of reaction can be recovered as high-pressure steam.;The catalyst used in the early Sohio process was a bismuth – phosphomolybdate combination. Since that time there has been a continuous search for alternatives and for superior performance, resulting in patents by more than 30 companies. Sohio introduced Catalyst 21 (antimony – uranium) in 1967, Catalyst 41 (ferrobismuth – phosphomolybdate) in 1972, and Catalyst 49 (undisclosed) in 1978. All of these changes were aimed at improved efficiency and reduction in byproducts.;;Simplified diagram of the Sohio acrylonitrile process. a) Fluidized-bed reactor; b) Absorber column; c) Extractive distillation column; d) Acetonitrile stripping column; e) Lights fractionation column; f) Product column;The reactor effluent is cooled and scrubbed with water in a countercurrent absorber. The off-gas, consisting primarily of nitrogen, is vented. The reaction products remain in the aqueous phase. Acetonitrile is removed by extractive distillation. Crude acrylonitrile and hydrogen cyanide are distilled overhead while water and acetonitrile are removed from the bottom of the columns. In subsequent distillations, hydrogen cyanide is separated from wet acrylonitrile, the water content of the product is then reduced, and finally, nonvolatile impurities are removed.;Unused ammonia can be recovered as ammonium sulfate and then disposed of, but it commonly is vented to the atmosphere. Aqueous wastes containing cyanides, sulfates, and various organic byproducts must be disposed of by incineration or deepwell injection or be pretreated for subsequent biological waste treatment;Reference:;Lollak, P., Romeder, G., Hagedorn, F., Gelbke, H.: Nitriles. In: Ullmann's Ency-clopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Seventh Edition, 2004 Electronic Release (ed. Fiedler E., Grossmann G., Kersebohm D., Weiss G. and Witte C.). 7 th Electronic Release Edition. Wiley InterScience, New York, Online-Version under: http://www.mrw.interscience.wiley.com/ueic/articles/
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Transports and emissions are modelled with standard methods.

exchanges.description:
Acrylonitrile s a colorless liquid with a slightly pungent odor. It is miscible with numerous organic solvents, including acetone, benzene, carbon tetrachloride, diethyl ether, ethyl acetate, ethylene cyanohydrin, petroleum ether, toluene, some kerosenes, 

Acrylic textile fibers are by far the largest end-use product for acrylonitrile. Acrylic fibers find use primarily in wearing apparel and in home furnishings such as carpets and draperies.

exchanges.description:
Calculation.  This data was calculated from the amount of unreacted ammonia and propylene in the treated waste water assuming a carbon conversion of 96% for COD and the worst case scenario: BOD=COD. 

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorized as emanating in a high population density area. The emissions into water are assumed to be emitted into rivers.

exchanges.description:
Estimation.  Air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated as 20% of the unreacted ammonia and 20% of the unreacted propylene.  

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

flow.name: Ammonia
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation.   Air emissions occurring from the purge vent, the distillation vent and fugitive emission sources were estimated to 20% of the raw material input. The propylene emissions are incinerated with an assumed destruction efficiency of 99.9% and are account for as CO2 emissions.

The carbon contained in the removed propylene during waste water treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air.

It is assumed that the manufacturing plants are located in an urban/industrial area and consequently the emissions are categorised as emanating in a high population density area.

flow.name: Carbon dioxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation.  Data was estimated based on the dataset "chemical plant, organics". This module assumes a built area of about 4.2 ha, an average output of 50'000 t/a, and plant life of fifty years.  The estimated value is 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.
